data.title: VSCode UI thread stops responding for half second every couple seconds

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Try editing a file with VSCode (tried HTML & TS files and both exhibit same problem)

This started happening after I installed VS2015 Update 3 (because VSCode kept wanting .NET Core 1.0 SDK or whatever it's called). It continues happening after I uninstalled VS2015 though.

I used a free screen recorder to show the issue but it's not the best. Hopefully it should give you an idea. First I try just holding down arrow to scroll through the file. You can see the freeze & jump. Then I try continuously typing. Again freeze then jump. This makes using VSCode VERY painful. Please let me know if there is any debugging info I can provide.

I cannot include a avi file with this bug report but it is available in this https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_bS6TUeSpxpNDBsTFB2dlRBamM/view?usp=sharing

data.title: "Open Preview to Right" not showing if "Option" key pressed before hovering
data.body:
Regarding #7666 and test item #9701
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insider (1.4.0-insider)
- OS Version: macOS El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Hold <kbd>Option</kbd> key while not hovering over the "Open Preview to Right" command.
2. Then hover over the "Open Preview to Right" command.

Note that it does not change the icon.  It only changes when you are already hovering over it and then press the key.

data.title: Extension Relevance Improvements

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
All versions of VS Code all OS.

Below are some examples where I think the extension sort order (relevance) is off.  In each case the most popular extension should also be the most relevant (based on the text match).
# C# - C# should be top

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1051190/17184200/d6c46746-53df-11e6-9b3e-a023e01a112b.png)
# Go - Go with Icon should be top

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1051190/17184229/fa12ea88-53df-11e6-8ff3-91921175ccc7.png)
# Python - Python with the transparent background should win

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1051190/17184284/42352ff6-53e0-11e6-86b1-c4cbf93f9f83.png)

cc: @waderyan

data.title: Highlight is persistent after deleting a code block
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3
- OS Version: Mac OS

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Highlight a block of code for deletion
2. Delete the code block
3. The highlight is persistent and now highlights some lines of code that replaces the deleted code block
4. This leads to unintentional deletion of newly highlighted line (say, if you press 'backspace' twice when trying to delete some whitespace before the initially highlighted code block)

data.title: Try to get rid of composite events in EventService
data.body: They should live in viewlet service / panel service

data.title: `compositeShown` telemetry event is one off
data.body:
1. Open Explorer
2. Open Extensions viewlet

The composite event after step 2 will be about the Explorer, not the Extensions viewlet.

data.title: Deleting searched phrase and closing file shows the deleted result in search pane
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use global search to search for something in your project
2. Open one of the results and delete the searched phrase from the file - at this point the search results show "no matches"
3. Save and close the file
4. The search result for the closed file shows the original line (that no longer exists) with the matched phrase

data.title: Search UX: Cancelling and Progress feedback

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insiders
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Project with large number of files
2. Search for something

Search will start running but then it will get stuck (or gets very slow - waited 15 min and did not finish) - CPU is at > 100%

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/17177175/226a4082-53de-11e6-98be-ded12c25ac16.png)

I know that there is related task to speed of search https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/55

But I would like to propose 2 small things that would help:
1. Ability to stop the search - especially if its very slow/stuck - right now the only option is to kill VSCode
2. Some progress indication so user can know that it is still searching (and not stuck) - eg. atom shows number of files that it searched 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/17177241/818d4cbc-53de-11e6-8307-9e52d98104a1.png)

data.title: UX meeting agenda 27 July 2016
data.body:
- gui: merge all 5 vscode consoles into 1 (like browsers do): https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9659
- close icon on terminal/console/etc. pane should be "x": https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9638 

We have a large number of issues with the UX label. I think we should start to triage these: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/labels/ux

data.title: Weird editor focus when clicking in dev tools
data.body:
While verifying #9759 I noticed that I can get vscode into a weird focus state. E.g both editors have focus and I see two cursors, or that the TS context menu actions are never present (due to the lack of focus I believe).
As explained in #9759,  open a TS writeable file, open dev tools (click something there), right click in the ts writeable file. Notice that sometimes the TS context menu actions are missing (and they do not return until a new file is opened) or two cursors can appear in different editors.

data.title: Incorrect highlighting of regular expression
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.3.1 - OS Version: Windows, OS X Steps to Reproduce: Enter the following in a new JavaScript, TypeScript, or TypeScript React document: ``` let a = true let url = "https://github.com/" let b = a ? /^[^:]+:\/\//.test(url) ? url : ('/' + url.replace(/^\.?\/?/, '')) : undefined; ``` Visual Studio Code incorrectly highlights the end of the first regular expression as a comment: Adding in parentheses leads to correct highlighting: I was only able to replicate this in ternary syntax, as the following highlights correctly:

data.title: Closing duplicate tab of file opens save prompt
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1607 Build 14388

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Split editor
2. Open same file in left and right editors
3. Edit the file in one of the editors
4. Close the file in the second editor

Prompts to save file before closing, and if no is chosen, discards changes made in the first editor. 

Expected behavior is to only force choice between saving and losing the edits when closing the only remaining open instance of the file.

5. So in step 3 I would expect to get completion to add a new empty object, and not word completions

```
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
         |trigger intellil-sense here
    ]
}
```

data.title: Cascading .vscode directory
data.body:
```
root
+-- projects
|    +-- .vscode
|        +-- settings.json
|    +-- project-a
|        +-- .vscode
|            +-- settings.json
|        +-- foo
|        +-- bar
|    +-- project-b
+-- work-projects
|    +-- project-foo
```
#### Expected results:

`~/projects/project-a/foo` & `~/projects/project-a/bar` are both affected by `~/projects/project-a/.vscode` > `~/projects/.vscode` > `defaults`

`~/projects/project-b` is however only affected by `~/projects/.vscode` > `defaults`

finally all projects in `~/work-projects` are only affected by the editor `defaults`
#### Use case:

My use case is that all repos in `~/projects/project-a` have a similar eslint setup that forces me to use `options.rulePaths` in settings, but when changing to `~/work-projects` the editor settings cause errors. but at the same time there is a lot of repo churn in that project directory, so adding the same setting everytime isn't ideal. Also at the same time including the settings in the repo would be commitment to a single editor.

data.title: [go] Reporting a small issue with code coloring when word `type` is present
data.body:
_From @RaviTezu on July 27, 2016 4:35_

![vscode-go](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3827937/17135213/3b0f4eda-534c-11e6-96d2-5f230c305b51.png)

As you can see from the above image line `Ftype String` looks different(color)
I think, `Ftype` is interpreted as an actual keyword `type` and it is changing the color of the next word(string in this case). I have checked this against Default and other themes and I can reproduce this on Mac(OS X El Capitan) and Ubuntu(14.04). 

vscode version: 1.3.1

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-go#408_

data.title: Unable to Install C# Extension
data.body:
- VSCode Version:     **1.2.0**
- OS Version:             **Windows 7 Professional Service Pack 1**

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Use `ctrl` + `shit` + `p` and type "install".
2.  When the list of available extensions appear, install any extension - this works fine.
3. Now, try the same, but try installing **C# for Visual Studio Code (powered by OmniSharp)**
4. VSCode attempts to install the extension, but after some time (about 30 seconds to a minute) this error appears: 

> Server returned 404

After this message appears, VSCode still looks like it is trying to install something in the bottom left corner. 

**Extra Details:**
I have the following settings in my settings.json file: 

```
// Place your settings in this file to overwrite the default settings
{
    "http.proxyStrictSSL": false,
    "git.autofetch": false
}
```

As I was not able to install any extensions before adding `"http.proxyStrictSSL": false`.
When I remove this line from my settings, I am again no longer able to search for extensions with this message: 

> Error unable to get local issuer certificate

data.title: Extend the API to add custom file opener
data.body:
I wanted to port the [pdf-view](https://github.com/izuzak/atom-pdf-view) extension for atom to vscode.

One thing that I came across that I don't know how to do it in vscode is atom's ability to add custom file openers: https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.8.0/Workspace#instance-addOpener

I'm pretty new to vscode so correct me if I'm wrong but without such API one would have to take a detour through the command palette to open a PDF file with pdfjs and the intuitive way via "Open File..." and (double) clicking on the file tree wouldn't work.

data.title: Could not create web workers when running mocha tests
data.body:
1. vscode repo, run mocha tests
2. notice the following warning:
   `Could not create web worker(s). Falling back to loading web worker code in main thread, which might cause UI freezes. Please see https://github.com/Microsoft/monaco-editor#faq
   Worker is not defined`
